> And what if the network does come to depend on that
> noise?  Read up on 
> Stephen Thaler and his Creativity Machine.  
> http://www.imagination-engines.com/thaler.htm

I remember hearing about this "Creativity Machine" a
while ago.  I was just reading some things on his
site.  He seems to think that his Creative Machine
paradigm is the ultimate solution for everything under
the sun.  It sounds like a lot of hype, but I guess
time will tell.  He does have some recent applications
that sound pretty good.

In a few places he talks about the inferiority of GAs
to his technique, usually worded in annoying ways. 
Here's a sample:

"In contrast, a genetic algorithm would require months
or even years to build as programmers capture all of
the implicit constraints that qualify a pattern of
pixels as a face. When finally run, the GA would
inevitably require years of run time, on the fastest
computers in the world to build a single coherent
face. ...That's why the Creativity [Machine] has been
heralded by top NASA officials as AI's best bet and
the primary tool for building the AI predicted by
Kurzweil and others in 30 years, now!"

So far I haven't found any good methods for robot
control that are as "self-training" as a GA since the
feedback is just so sparse, but apparently Thaler's
method has been used to train robots.  I guess I'm
open to new ideas...

I'm wondering if anyone has any more info on this. 
I'd like to get some info from an unbiased source
(i.e. not the super-hyped stuff from the Imagination
Engines website).

Tyler
